_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Applicable building, electrical, and plumbing codes. This facility complies with the Iowa Fertilizer Law.
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: We utilize those portions of these codes which are deemed applicable by the jurisdictional authority
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Breakaway couplers at the risers and  emergency shutoff valve at the storage tank, emergency shutoff in the NH3 scale shed
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Regular plant inspections/Routine preventative maintenance & repairs

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE
This facility complies with ANSI Standard K-61.1-1999 requirements with amendments for
Anhydrous Ammonia storage. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal, State, and local
regulations. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to immediately notify the Volunteer Fire Department (via a 911 call) and request that it respond to the emergency. Incidental to the
notification to the fire department, a call to the Cerro Gordo EMA will be made.
While we have planned for an emergency, it is acknowledged that a real emergency will be
unexpected and may very well be much different and cannot be ensured to duplicate what may have been planned. In reality, the situation that develops may not happen in the manner in which it has been planned. In that event, what may have been planned will serve only as a guideline to follow.
The Emergency Action Plan for this facility describes certain procedures that are intended to
minimize the hazards associated with human health and the environment from fires, explosions, then sudden and unexpected release of chemicals (i.e., Anhydrous Ammonia), tornadoes, bomb threats or other accidents or acts of God which might occur on our premises. The primary emergency coordinator for this location is location manager.
DESCRIPTION OF THE ANHYDROUS AMMONIA STORAGE/DISTRIBUTION PLANT AND THE
REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED AT LOCATION
This facility is a bulk anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution plant. The anhydrous ammonia that is stored at this facility is distributed to agricultural crop producers in the surrounding area who utilize the anhydrous ammonia for crop nutrient purposes.
The system consists of multiple storage vessels tanks with associated piping, valves, liquid pump(s), and other miscellaneous equipment. From time-to-time throughout the year numerous portable nurse tanks may also be present at this site. The anhydrous ammonia plant is only operated on a seasonal basis (Spr

ing and Fall). Full-time equivalent employee numbers were computed on that basis. At a maximum, the plant operates a total of three months (1/4 of the year). The FTEs for this company location are one (4).
GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC
PREVENTION STEPS:
This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable State and local codes and regulations. The anhydrous ammonia system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with ANSI Standard K-61.1-1999 with amendments and State law.
In addition the company has specific operating procedures in place intended to minimize the
potential for an accidental (and potentially catastrophic) release of anhydrous ammonia. Finally, the company has extended to the fire department the opportunity to visit our anhydrous ammonia plant, to participate in mock emergency simulation training, and to avail themselves of specific anhydrous ammonia health hazard information and training provided by the company.
FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:
Location has never had an accident involving anhydrous ammonia that caused death, injuries,
property or environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering in place.
THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:
In the event of an emergency involving our anhydrous ammonia system, it is the policy of the
company to immediately notify the fire department and the Cerro Gordo EMA to request that they respond to the emergency. In the unlikely event that the Thornton Fire Department is unable to adequately respond to an emergency, the fire department with whom the location has a reciprocal agreement will be summoned. 
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:
The plan is to minimize those hazards to human health and to the environment that are associated with accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. Employees working at the bulk storage plant make routine observations prior to and during transfer operations of the anhydrous ammonia from the storage vessel(s) to nurse tan

ks. In so doing, they are able to detect problems before they arise. This routine inspection identifies any portion of the system which may be under stress or about to fail. Repairs can be made before they become problematic. Employees are annually trained to recognize the hazards associated with storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia. In addition to annual training for employees who have been on the job for a number of years, the company conducts training for new hires. This training includes classroom instruction, on-site training at the plant, and follow-up observation to determine their individual comprehension and understanding of the new hire. Finally, the company routinely invites local fire department personnel to visit the site. In the event that the local fire department requests assistance in training its employees on anhydrous ammonia, the company cooperates fully in their endeavors.
